Indstruktibl Clothing is a distinctive clothing company, founded by Chad Addie in late 2009. The idea was conceptualized on Milwaukee’s famed east side, in a run-down, disheveled college dwelling. What began as merely curiosity turned into countless late-night design sessions, which progressed into the creation of one-off t-shirt designs for friends and family members. Consumer interest was undeniably present, so Chad carried the idea a step further. His efforts evolved into a full-fledged limited liability company.

Our company’s mission is to provide unique, high-quality apparel to our customers. We approach our business with the intention of conquering conformity, and our products and company name reflect that notion. Our clothing caters to the toughest athletes, the rawest of bands, and to everyone who desires a distinctive, inimitable style.

At Indstruktibl Clothing, we take pride in creating hand-crafted works of art for our customers. Each shirt is made for you with premium fabric, hand-finished washes, unique details, and most importantly, an excellent fit. You'll love the individual character and comfort of everything you purchase from us.
Help Us Launch Our First Ever Full Line

By pledging towards our project you're making our first full line possible this summer. The cost of large runs of these high quality products can be overwhelming.  If we reach our funding goal, we will help to keep work in America through our printers, manufacturers and designers.
If you pledge to our project, you will be the first to receive products from our all new line this summer. Here are some examples of our current products.

You will be helping to bring jobs back to America and create job security for those already employed in the production industry. From our local printers Redwall Printing in Milwaukee, WI, to the suppliers of our blanks at American Apparel, to the designers that create these hand-made works of art.

All of our design is done at our studio in Chicago, IL. After the design is complete, our blanks are stitched in Los Angeles, California at American Apparel. The blanks are then shipped to our printers in Milwaukee, WI where they are printed/embroidered.
Our pledges will be allocated across the following areas:
This is the amount that we need to fulfill all minimum requirements on our apparel production. This cost includes fabric, manufacturing, screen-printing, and any embroidery.

This amount will cover the cost of a booth at the Surf Expo in Orlando, FL this September. The expo will be a great opportunity to spread the word about our company to a large audience and help get us into boutiques and retail stores across America.

We know that we create the highest quality apparel in the industry today, but we need to spread that information to everyone else. These funds will go towards a full advertising campaign to go along with our summer line. (Facebook Ads, Twitter Ads, Google Ad Words, flyers, posters, SEO etc.)

We believe that every part of your order should be beautiful when you receive it at your doorstep. This means custom packaging that reinforces the reasons you purchased products from us. You're looking for a unique experience, and we will provide that to you!
And that's it. All expenses combined, we need $30,000 to make this dream we created into a reality. Thank you for your support!

The shooting and production of this video was done by Chad Addie with the help of friends and family. We had no budget to work with, but we worked hard to make something from our hearts. We hope that it gave you a better idea of what we're all about.

We want to make Indstruktibl a household name in America. We want it to inspire others as much as it inspires us. We believe that every order we send out could make a difference in someone's life. Anyone can be Indstruktibl if they strive to be the greatest in what they do everyday.
Thank you so much for your support, it truly means a lot to us!
Special thanks to Daniel Wu, The Good Fight Studios, and Robert Richard for the help!
Visit www.indclothing.com and learn more about us!

The most immediate challenge we will face is getting everything designed, produced, and sent to your doorstep. At Indstruktibl Clothing, we know all about hard work and we have no intention of slowing down now. We will do whatever it takes to get our products to you in a timely manner. We know we have something great here and you will not be disappointed in your decision to support our dreams!

NaviPack makes any device smarter and easier to control. It uses the latest LiDAR technology and powerful APIs to create easy solutions for automated devices.

column1: With the built-in SLAM algorithm chip, Navipack is the first plug-and-play type of LIDAR navigation module. NaviPack is also the most affordable LiDAR solution for drones, robots and other devices and instantly enables them with powerful 360-degree sensing capabilities.
NaviPack integrates the SLAM algorithm with the LiDAR sensor module, making it super easy to use and significantly reducing development time.

NaviPack performs 360 degree scanning of its surroundings and all objects up to 15 meters away with a frequency of 4000 points per second. It is super easy to use! With the built-in SLAM module, it will start working immediately after plugging into your devices - scanning the environment, building a detailed map, and enabling auto-moving capability.

Navipack sensors can be 4000 points per second frequency of continuous scanning and perception of the surrounding environment, we will provide a different hardware interface and API allows you to deep integration of Navipack and UAV.
With NaviPack, the device will always find the best route to take after you give it a destination to move to.
NaviPack can be applied to the robots as their brain. Once plugged in NaviPack will manage the robot to avoid obstacles automatically.

column2: >

column1: Navipack's simple operation and useful features make it easy for students to add it onto a variety of carriers enabling them to move autonomously. Navipack has many common interfaces that can be combined with multiple sensors to enhance the versatility of the carrier for endless creative possibilities for students and hobbyists.

column6: s=af1d130a9249b78d8760b45fe2ad6360"" src="""" style='font-family: ""Benton Sans"", Helvetica, sans-serif

column1: NaviPack can quickly construct and memorize its surrounding area. When there are other objects detected, NaviPack will immediately perceive whether it is a live person or other machinery and will track its trajectory to avoid any possible collision.
The software is currently compatible with ROS, Linux, Windows, Android and other systems. In addition, we also provide the APP source code for development options for iPhone and iPad.

A complete SDK interface is provided which allows developers a method for significant autonomous navigation research and development. The SDK works with Windows, Linux and Android operating systems with a Windows and Android demo program. Additionally, the NaviPack system provides a Web / Web Socket operation interface which can facilitate the development of PC programs based on NaviPack.

The SDK interface includes independent navigation, manual mapping, positioning navigation, map management and other basic navigation functions. Additional functions similar to automatic backfilling, custom sensor inputs and more are also provided. With the NaviPack system, developers will enjoy the option to expand sensor options and enhance the performance of existing NaviPack features.
You can tell NaviPack to build a map using a graphical interface. The map can be built using either manual or automated methods.

When you need to redefine your location, you can use the positioning interface to re-determine location. An important feature of NaviPack is that when the navigation system detects that the immediate location varies from the map, autonomous re-positioning will occur. If you want your robot to move from one place to another, simply issue a command. At that point with the help of NaviPack it will create the best route and intelligently proceed, adjusting route or position as necessary if any obstacles are encountered.
The NaviPack SDK supports the export of information from various sensors and the algorithm with one simple instruction. The SDK can easily collect all the data from a variety of sensors.
Through the log interface, you can very clearly monitor and record the various activity information of NaviPack.
NaviPack is very simple to use. You can connect with NaviPack through Serial Port, USB, or WIFI.

With NaviKit you are free to dream and create. It works with NaviCamera, a powerful 3D TOF in-depth camera and NaviPanel, a robot ready component that is ready to roll. NaviKit includes everything you need to build and go in one step!
NaviPack can be used in conjunction with the identification of obstacles in different locations, but also can be applied to somatosensory games, 3D modeling and more.
NaviCamera uses a complex TOF program, with a pixel size of 80 * 60, you can measure the depth of the object within the scope of 0.2-7M information, precision error to mm level.

NaviPanel is small but powerful robotics kit. The three-wheeled platform can carry loads up to 30kg. It has five ultrasonic sensors and four geodetic sensors and includes the NaviPack module for navigation.
All of the necessary hardware is included, it is the perfect ready-to-roll kit for developers and great for DIY projects.
Delivering NaviPack on time is really important to us.
Hardware products are heavily contingent on budget and manufacturing time. We have years of experience producing hardware products and are well aware of how to avoid potential problems.
However, we realize that issues sometimes arise despite our best efforts to plan for them. We will keep you up to date on all our progress and be transparent about our outlook at every stage.
Q1：What is the difference between NaviPack and other LiDAR products on the market?

A：NaviPack integrates the SLAM algorithm and sensor into one. By combining NaviPack with the software in this way, it instantly achieves important functions such as intelligent obstacle avoidance and smart path planning, greatly reducing debugging time for developers.
A：With NaviPack, developers can achieve motor controls by simply enabling communication between the carrier and the NaviPack algorithm.

A: NaviPack using INMOTION independent research and development for optical coupling technology, eliminating the need for a middle slip ring. This results in a substantial increase in service life and more stable performance in a small overall structure.
Q4：Can NaviPack software access ultrasonic and anti-drop sensors?
A：You can access RGBD, ultrasonic, anti-drop, collision and other sensors can be accessed by way of LiDAR USB, HDMI, UART interface access.
Q5: What information does the carrier need to transmit to NaviPack?

A: Carrier is mainly used to send a variety of sensor data to the NaviPack such as encoder data according to the communication protocol. Important factors are sensor data transmission frequency, the sensor sampling period and communications that remain overloaded. The recommended speed for encoder data is 10ms.
Q6：Is NaviPack's laser dangerous to human eyes?
A：NaviPack uses a low-power infrared laser as a light source, the laser is activated only for a very short periods of time and maintains Class 1 laser safety standards to remain safe for human eyes.
A：NaviPack includes LiDAR software as well WEB side information display and control software and APP source code.
Q8：What are the parameters of NaviPanel and which sensors are included?
A：The NaviPanel size is Φ352 * 146, the motor is a single side 10W, with movement speed of 0.05m / s ~ 0.06m / s. It contains five ultrasonic sensors, four geodetic sensors and a NaviPack.
Q9：Will NaviPanel be equipped with a battery?
A：NaviPanel will not be equipped with batteries due to international transport policies. Developers can use 12V, 10A batteries.
A: Power + data serial port, Micro USB, Serial port debug, HDMI interface and

Fashion Envie

Welcome to our fundraising page! My name is Jennifer Nnamani, founder of Beau Monde Society and creator of Fashion Envie. BMS is an eco-focused fashion startup  with one goal in mind
column2: to build a sustainable future through our contributions, our support of ethical fashion initiatives, and partnership across different industries in promoting a better world. Since our launch in 2013, we have remained true to our mission by working with independent fashion designers and creatives that are celebrating higher ideals.

column1: During a long train ride from Brooklyn back uptown, I was with a good friend of mine, Tamara Leacock of Reciclagem NY--who also happens to be an ethical fashion designer. I told her that I've noticed that there aren't enough platforms to highlight eco-friendly fashion and she agreed. I vowed then that I would start something (being in the fashion industry briefly as a model, I didn't witness enough sustainable fashion designers). I wasn't sure when I would start but I knew something must be done about it. This conversation took place in the Fall of 2012. Soon after, I had to find a name that would symbolize what I am trying to accomplish. There are so many fashion events in New York City and I didn't want this event to not have some meaning-- some purpose. After a few play with words, I came up with Fashion Envie meaning Fashion, Environment, &
column2: Life--I chose April as that's Earth Month as supposed to February as it will conflict with  New York Fashion Week calendar.

column1: As soon as I had the official event name and month, I embarked on instituting a company-- a brand that will encompass my versatile skill sets and in turn, act as an entity that will introduce the platform to the world. Beau Monde Society came after Fashion Envie. The mission of BMS is to approach unique projects by focusing on lifestyle branding while fusing fashion, creativity, and functional ideas to sustain brand awareness and ethical responsibility. Through our annual eco-collective, we have featured designers from different design backgrounds and inspirations. BMS has also offered them an array of creative services such as PR, brand consultation, social media strategies for an affordable fee. I know how difficult it can be to have a day job and at the same time, working almost 25 hours a day to make your dreams come true and not wanting to ask for any help because you can't afford it or not sure where to look for it. I've heard their stories and I know the importance of giving back or connecting them with the right people.
Fashion Envie offers our designers that platform to promote themselves/story/brand to diverse and eco-conscious guests (both new and seasoned).
column2:
>Plus, our designers get an opportunity to showcase their designs in ways they haven't done before. Some of the designers that have been featured in Fashion Envie shared that that was their first fashion showcase. For this year's installation entitled Oxo M o n o c h r o m e, we are adding two new features:

  • 1st ever F.U.N Roundtable Discussion: We are inviting members of the press to partake in a conversational series with our designers and other distinguished panelists to discuss ""Sustainable Future"" and how they are each adding something of value to that conversation. Our designers will also have a chance to have a one on one interview with press and promote their brand in significant ways. This event will be held at the Gibney Dance Theater
  • Pop-up meets Fashion Presentation: This year's FE will feature a fashion presentation style setup as well as an opportunity for designers to sell their ""Ready to Wear"" designs, jewelry etc to guests that attend our day II on April 23rd at Caelum Art Gallery.

column1:
What We Need 

  • Promotional Materials: Event flier design, printing needs (we are reducing our carbon footprint by promoting our event solely online and printing only what's needed), and Green Wall revamp (our version of step and repeat wall to feature all our designer's logos, sponsors, and partners).
  • Entertainment: Music plays a crucial role in the curation of our event. With your small donation, our event can come to life.

• Extra Props:  To go along with this year's theme, we will be renting out event props such as special lightning, interior decor, and gift bags for our guests
  • Miscellaneous: Transportation and travel stipends for interns/volunteers, pre-event food lunch for creative team, models, and volunteers.
• PERKS: With a $ 20 support, you will receive a 2 day event pass to Fashion Envie
• As a Fashion Envie supporter, you will receive an opportunity to meet our designers and shop their products before Fashion Envie's fashion presentation.
• We will add more perks as our list of in-kind sponsors grow :)
• If we don't make our goal, we will use all of the funds to an amazing 4th installation. Thank you!
• Fashion Envie meaning Fashion, Environment, and Life, highlights the interdependent relationship between these three important components.
• Since our first installation, we have featured 10 independent and emerging designers in a curated space. We have provided them with press, a creative team, and feedback on their designing journey.

• Our fundamental goal is to create a FUN atmosphere for all of our guests to enjoy--to have an experience like none other. A fashion presentation that awakens the senses and propagates the inevitable truth of efforts that our designers have taken to reduce environmental waste. By fusing fashion, art, and music, we have successfully created a platform that would showcase designers in a memorable and inspiring light.

column2:
Challenges

In creating a eco-focused fashion presentation featuring eco-friendly designs, there have been some challenges and risks.

column1: • Challenges that have arisen are lack of familiarity with the designers and for some companies, the inability to allot funds/products due to their budgetary limitations, and increasing our press reach-- once again due to lack of familiarity. However, resiliency and consistency has yielded positive results.
• Sponsors are eager to support a platform such as FE due to the lack of representation for eco-friendly designers.

• Suitable location: FE's aesthetics thrive in a blank art space where we are able to transform the event space into our eco-collective theme. Finding suitable and affordable locations have become very rare and difficult.

• By building an information press packet, sponsors are made aware of our past progress as well as future goals that we aim to accomplish through Fashion Envie. Another effective way to increase our press reach include and are not limited to expanding our network, expanding our search for writers passionate about the environment, and locations that would increase our overall reach as well.

• Fashion as a culture is the most meaningful medium to transmit new ideas. By bringing eco-fashion into the conversation, Fashion Envie's mission is to provide a platform for independent designers as well as creating a F.U.N landscape to ensure its longevity and impact towards a sustainable future. By joining our annual ecoventure, you can support Fashion Envie by making a contribution and/or spreading the word about our exciting eco-collective.
• Support our campaign by placing a monetary contribution. No amount is too small.
• Share our indiegogo links as much as you can on all your social media platforms by using the Indiegogo share tools!
• Support the locally-based designers that work with Beau Monde Society and other small businesses in your area.

About The Shoe

Kenya defines running excellence. Successive generations of athletes have come to understand and have perfected the art of running. Working together with them, we have created the ultimate running shoe.

Throughout a year of design, development and testing, we strictly followed two principles:

First: We knew our shoe had to be worthy of the Kenyan running tradition, which is second to none. We relied on expert craftsmanship and the best available materials at every turn in order to produce a top quality shoe.

Second: We wanted a shoe that meets the needs of runners around the world by incorporating lessons from running in Kenya. 

We’re confident that we’ve made a shoe that fits both of those criteria: the Enda Iten, our debut design named after a small nondescript town in Kenya known for producing running champions.

 

Technical Features

 

4mm Drop: The difference between the thickness of padding at the heel and under the forefoot can make a big difference on the way you run. Put too much foam under the heel relative to the forefoot, and you’re at risk of the thick heel hitting first and throwing off your gait. Put too little, and you might not have enough cushion under your heel when going downhill or over rough terrain. If you watch just about any Kenyan runner, you’ll notice they land on their mid-foot or balls of their feet. So we’ve given the Iten a 4mm heel to toe drop, which is about half of most traditional running shoes.

Wider Toe Box: We created more space for the pinky toe than is found in many other shoes to ensure it’s not squished into or under its neighbor. A natural toe splay helps to absorb impact, which is why we went a bit wider to give the pinky some room to do its work

Light Weight - 7.9 oz (224 grams):  Lots of running shoes are classed as either trainers (read: thick and padded) or racing flats (read: thin and lots of ground feel). The Iten sits between those categories. With 21mm of cushioning under under heel and 17mm under forefoot, it's a shoe you can comfortably train in, but it's fast enough for race day.

Midsole as Heel Counter: while the Iten is a 4mm drop shoe, we realize it looks like it has more of heel than this. That’s because we brought the midsole up to cup the heel. When viewed from behind you get a sense of how much the foot really sits down into the midsole. This helps the shoe move with your foot when you’re running on terrain that might have your foot hitting at a funny angle or rolling a bit.

Full Rubber Outsole: this gives you grip and protection on pavement and on other surfaces, such as light trails. If you land on a small rock, you won’t feel it the way you might on a shoe with a less substantial outsole. Since it’s real rubber, it will also stick around through hundreds of miles, giving your Enda Iten’s almost as much endurance as you.

 

The Kenyan Heritage

We drew inspiration from different elements of Kenya, including its rich history:

1. Colors: these have been selected to match the Kenyan flag.

2. Our Logo: it’s design is based on the image of a spear tip. The spear features throughout the history of Kenyan national identity, from the flag to being one of the highest honors that can be awarded to an individual in Kenya (Elder of the Burning Spear) — not unlike a knighthood or a presidential commendation.

3. Harambee Philosophy: Under the sole, you'll find the word ""Harambee"". It's the official motto of Kenya, and a value that drives us as a company. In Swahili it means “all pull together”, and is used to refer to moments where communities come together to accomplish something individuals couldn’t do alone – just as we are turning to you to ask for help in making Kenyan running shoes a reality.

4. The Number 12: Jamhuri Day (Republic Day), the most important national holiday marking both the date Kenya gained independence in 1963 and the day, exactly one year later, when Kenya became a republic, is on the twelfth of December - or 12/12. That's why we’ve got exactly 12 lines on the lateral side of the Enda Iten.

5. The Great Rift Valley: most of Kenya’s running champions come from the rift valley. To honor them, and the valley’s unique high-altitude and mild climate that makes for the best training grounds in the world, the heel of Enda Itens is designed to mimic the valley and its great escarpments.

6. Geometric Patterns and Repeating Triangle Motifs: these feature in many traditional Kenyan fabrics and beaded patterns. We've brought three variations of these patterns into the side mesh, the heel strap at the back and the outsole.

We hope you enjoy these little bits of Kenya and find the Iten’s a pair of shoes you’ll want to wear both out on a run and about town.

 

Sizing

The critical thing for determining sizing is the last - a foot shaped mold around which the shoe is built. We worked with Jones &
column2: Vining, who have over 80 years’ experience in developing lasts, because they’re well known in the shoe industry to be best in class. Using their lasts means the Enda Iten will fit true to size.

column1: • If you don’t know your running shoe size, don't worry. You don't need to tell us until the campaign ends. Between now and then, there are a couple of things you can do:
• You can go to a running or sporting goods store near you and try on a couple of shoes. Odds are the size for a Saucony Kinvara or Nike Free 5.0 will be the right size for your Enda Itens.

• If you can’t make it into a store, then consider that most people wear a running shoe that is slightly larger than normal shoe, since our feet swell when we run and you want a bit of extra room to move forward when running downhill. If you normally wear shoes that have a bit of room in the toe, just order that size. If your shoes are snug, then you might want to order your Enda Iten’s a half-size larger.

How It’s Made

The long term goal is for all components of Enda shoes to be made start to finish in Kenya. Sadly, a great deal of the equipment necessary to make a great running shoe simply can’t be found in Kenya. So we’re starting simple, with a plan to build on as we go.

This means that, initially, we’ll be sourcing the component pieces from Asia, and then building the shoes and packaging them here in Kenya. For the components we’re using two excellent facilities in China that also produce running shoes for other major international running shoe brands. 

 

How We Got Here

Making the Enda Iten has been a long process. It started out as an idea to make a truly Kenyan running shoe. In the 18 months since that start, we've worked with talented and experienced shoe designers, developers, and professional runners to create the ultimate running shoe. Two of the leading figures in this process have been:

Steve Burris - Steve’s passion for running and coaching led him to join the original product development team at Nike’s Exeter, NH R&
column2: D facility in the late 1970’s. He developed numerous commercially successful sport-shoe models for customers and world class athletes. In a 38 year career in athletic footwear &amp
column3:
apparel, Steve led global product development teams for adidas in Germany and Reebok in the USA and was production Country Manager in several Southeast Asian source countries. Steve has managed large organization logistics with notable success, and more recently assisted smaller brands such as Newton Running, and start-up brands in setting up product sourcing organizations. But his passion remains high performance product which helps athletes at every level maximize their potential. Steve retains excellent relationships with suppliers and infrastructure providers across the industry and is highly respected for his ability to build world class product sourcing capabilities which achieve the best balance of quality, timely delivery and pricing.

Birdhaus Design -  With a team bringing experience Under Armour, Reebok, and Keen, Birdhaus is well versed in designing and manufacturing top quality athletic shoes. Birdhaus uses design thinking and strategy to deliver innovative solutions to clients around the world.

We've gone through many iterations of the design and created many prototypes in order to build a pair of shoes that are a joy to run in, while still looking great when wearing them around town. Through that process we've built a team of people around us - freelancers, volunteers, and suppliers - that make it feel like anything is possible with the shoe. We're excited to keep working with them to bring you this shoe and hopefully produce more shoes in the future.

 

About This Campaign

We're excited to be asking the Indiegogo community for support because it means we can offer you the first ever Enda Iten shoes as a reward. 

Rewards

Of course the prime reward is a pair of Enda Iten running shoes, but we've got a couple of other things going on. You'll find that we've paired these various offerings as stand alone items or in groups. Here's what you'll find:

Thank You Mentions On Our Website - On a specially reserved space on our website, we will write your name and honour you for believing in us when all we had was nothing but a dream - and a prototype!

Bracelets with the Kenyan flag on one side and Enda on the other. These have been designed and handmade with love from two different places - a small shop in Iten and by women from around the Maasai Mara area.

T- Shirts - show off your first run with these cool running tees paired up with your Enda Itens. They're made in Kenya of course. Only available in black for the moment.

 

About Enda

Enda (meaning ""Go!""in Swahili) is a social enterprise founded to bring Kenyan athletic greatness to runners around the world, and to bring sustainable income to Kenya. Enda was founded in 2015 as a Benefit Corporation by Navalayo (Nava) Osembo-Ombati and Weldon Kennedy.

Nava comes from a village near Eldoret, Kenya, where many of Kenya’s running champions come from. A graduate of the London School of Economics, Navalayo has worked in different places around the world, including the US, UK, Ethiopia, Tanzania and Kenya. She is trained as both an accountant and a lawyer, which explains why she is so interested in risk management, results-based management and writing.

Weldon is a social-change campaigner who has worked on a range of early stage social change startups. He built the student and international member programs at The ONE Campaign and most recently led Change.org's growth in Europe as the regional Managing Director. An avid runner and running shoe obsessive, his half marathon PB is 1:37:39.

We met in Nairobi in early 2015 and immediately clicked. After a couple of conversations we decided to found Enda because we believe Kenya can, and should, benefit more from it’s well earned running reputation, and because we believe it will be good for runners everywhere to have a stronger connection to the culture and traditions of Kenyan running.

 

Social Impact

We are a social enterprise with a mission of increasing the amount Kenya benefits from its well earned reputation in running greatness. We’re working with social impact consultants, Global &
column4:
Smart, to ensure that we’re building a company that has creating social value at it’s core right from the start.

1. Creating Jobs 

This is pretty straight forward. Kenya is a young country with a median age of 18 years. Frustratingly, youth unemployment in Kenya is 17%. Development experts and the Kenyan government agree that creating good jobs in sectors like manufacturing is one of the most important priorities for the country.

The challenge is that it is almost always cheaper and easier to produce goods in Southeast Asia. We plan on overcoming this obstacle by creating a brand that leverages the value of being made in Kenya, as well as taking advantage of preferential of tariff rates for importing footwear and apparel to the US under the African Growth and Opportunity Act. The result will be bringing some quality jobs to Kenya.

2. Supporting Local Communities

Many Kenyans lack access to basic sanitation, clean water, adequate health care, and quality education. Thankfully many clever and courageous people are working to address these challenges. From experience, we know how hard it is for them to fund their activities. We want to make sure we’re making our contribution too, so here’s how we’re going to do this:

column1: <li>We’ll set aside a portion of our profits into a pool (of money, not for swimming!)
column2: Working with experts, we’ll identify a handful of most effective projects that could use some extra support every 6 months

column1: <li>Anyone who buys a pair of Enda shoes and registers their purchase will get one vote to help us determine which projects will receive money from the pool
• Through this, we will link Enda runners across the globe to local communities in Kenya, and vice versa, and encourage empathy, creativity and innovation.

3. Changing The Way the World Sees Kenya

Kenya is already famous for the world’s best runners, stunning wildlife, fantastic beaches, and where President Obama’s father came from (never mind the rest of our species some 60,000 years ago). We want to make it famous for great products too.

Most people couldn’t tell you exactly where their shoes are made. We want Enda runners to be able to take pride in knowing their running kit comes from Kenya, and that Kenyan products are of the highest quality. 

Share Enda On Social Media

Think we're amazing? Well then, don't keep it to yourself! Follow us on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram and share us with your family and friends!!!

Risks and challenges

We don’t think we’re the first people to think up the idea of making running shoes in Kenya. Certainly the idea has dawned on others, but they haven’t done it because it’s a downright difficult thing to do. Here are the top challenges we foresee, though knowing they might come up, we’re already working hard to mitigate their potential impact.

Import and Export Challenges - there are an increasing number of companies bringing materials into Kenya and exporting finished goods. The more companies do it, the smoother the process becomes. Still, the port at Mombasa is known to be challenging and slowdowns can occur. We’ll work with the best handling agents to mitigate this risk and hopefully be able to assemble and ship our shoes on schedule.

Shipping and Delivery - There may be other fees, forms or legalities we are unaware of that could block shipments of the shoes or cause them to be delayed or returned. While we're not experts on tax and other fees applicable to every country, we will do our best to ensure that your order arrives on time.

Consistency and Quality Control - when we start putting together a large volume of shoes for the first time, we’ll have to work hard to ensure they are consistently of the highest quality. We’re factoring this into our costs, and anticipate that there will be some shoes early on that won’t be up to our standards so we'll have some shoes we can’t ship.

Achieving Social Good Goals - all of our social good goals depend on us becoming a sustainable and scalable business. This Indiegogo campaign will get things rolling, but we’ll only really start creating jobs and revenue to Kenya if the attention and funds from the campaign get us to the point where we’re producing and selling a steady stream of shoes. So we’re already diving into a marketing plan for online sales, and will start selling to stores for the Spring 2017 season.

Sizing - we’ve worked hard to ensure our shoes run true to size. However, there’s always a chance that slight variations in foot shape mean that an Enda runner finds they need a slightly different size from their other running shoes. We’ll be using a distribution service to ensure returns are handled smoothly and efficiently.

Production Speed - making prototypes and a full production run are two totally different things, and there are likely unforeseen pitfalls we aren’t seeing yet. We don’t want to over-promise on this first production run, so we’ve added in extra padding on our production timelines. If we have any doubt that we’ll be able to hit delivery timelines we’ll be open and forthcoming so you know when to expect the shoes.

The Number 12: Jamhuri Day (Republic Day), the most important national holiday marking both the date Kenya gained independence in 1963 and the day, exactly one year later, when Kenya became a republic, is on the twelfth of December - or 12/12. That's why we’ve got exactly 12 lines on the lateral side of the Enda Iten.5. The Great Rift Valley: most of Kenya’s running champions come from the rift valley. To honor them, and the valley’s unique high-altitude and mild climate that makes for the best training grounds in the world, the heel of Enda Itens is designed to mimic the valley and its great escarpments.6. Geometric Patterns and Repeating Triangle Motifs: these feature in many traditional Kenyan fabrics and beaded patterns. We've brought three variations of these patterns into the side mesh, the heel strap at the back and the outsole.We hope you enjoy these little bits of Kenya and find the Iten’s a pair of shoes you’ll want to wear both out on a run and about town. SizingThe critical thing for determining sizing is the last - a foot shaped mold around which the shoe is built. We worked with Jones & Vining, who have over 80 years’ experience in developing lasts, because they’re well known in the shoe industry to be best in class. Using their lasts means the Enda Iten will fit true to size.
If you don’t know your running shoe size, don't worry. You don't need to tell us until the campaign ends. Between now and then, there are a couple of things you can do:
You can go to a running or sporting goods store near you and try on a couple of shoes. Odds are the size for a Saucony Kinvara or Nike Free 5.0 will be the right size for your Enda Itens.

If you can’t make it into a store, then consider that most people wear a running shoe that is slightly larger than normal shoe, since our feet swell when we run and you want a bit of extra room to move forward when running downhill. If you normally wear shoes that have a bit of room in the toe, just order that size. If your shoes are snug, then you might want to order your Enda Iten’s a half-size larger.

How It’s MadeThe long term goal is for all components of Enda shoes to be made start to finish in Kenya. Sadly, a great deal of the equipment necessary to make a great running shoe simply can’t be found in Kenya. So we’re starting simple, with a plan to build on as we go.This means that, initially, we’ll be sourcing the component pieces from Asia, and then building the shoes and packaging them here in Kenya. For the components we’re using two excellent facilities in China that also produce running shoes for other major international running shoe brands.  How We Got HereMaking the Enda Iten has been a long process. It started out as an idea to make a truly Kenyan running shoe. In the 18 months since that start, we've worked with talented and experienced shoe designers, developers, and professional runners to create the ultimate running shoe. Two of the leading figures in this process have been:Steve Burris - Steve’s passion for running and coaching led him to join the original product development team at Nike’s Exeter, NH R&D facility in the late 1970’s. He developed numerous commercially successful sport-shoe models for customers and world class athletes. In a 38 year career in athletic footwear & apparel, Steve led global product development teams for adidas in Germany and Reebok in the USA and was production Country Manager in several Southeast Asian source countries. Steve has managed large organization logistics with notable success, and more recently assisted smaller brands such as Newton Running, and start-up brands in setting up product sourcing organizations. But his passion remains high performance product which helps athletes at every level maximize their potential. Steve retains excellent relationships with suppliers and infrastructure providers across the industry and is highly respected for his ability to build world class product sourcing capabilities which achieve the best balance of quality, timely delivery and pricing.Birdhaus Design -  With a team bringing experience Under Armour, Reebok, and Keen, Birdhaus is well versed in designing and manufacturing top quality athletic shoes. Birdhaus uses design thinking and strategy to deliver innovative solutions to clients around the world.We've gone through many iterations of the design and created many prototypes in order to build a pair of shoes that are a joy to run in, while still looking great when wearing them around town. Through that process we've built a team of people around us - freelancers, volunteers, and suppliers - that make it feel like anything is possible with the shoe. We're excited to keep working with them to bring you this shoe and hopefully produce more shoes in the future. About This CampaignWe're excited to be asking the Indiegogo community for support because it means we can offer you the first ever Enda Iten shoes as a reward. RewardsOf course the prime reward is a pair of Enda Iten running shoes, but we've got a couple of other things going on. You'll find that we've paired these various offerings as stand alone items or in groups. Here's what you'll find:Thank You Mentions On Our Website - On a specially reserved space on our website, we will write your name and honour you for believing in us when all we had was nothing but a dream - and a prototype!Bracelets with the Kenyan flag on one side and Enda on the other. These have been designed and handmade with love from two different places - a small shop in Iten and by women from around the Maasai Mara area.T- Shirts - show off your first run with these cool running tees paired up with your Enda Itens. They're made in Kenya of course. Only available in black for the moment. About EndaEnda (meaning ""Go!""in Swahili) is a social enterprise founded to bring Kenyan athletic greatness to runners around the world, and to bring sustainable income to Kenya. Enda was founded in 2015 as a Benefit Corporation by Navalayo (Nava) Osembo-Ombati and Weldon Kennedy.Nava comes from a village near Eldoret, Kenya, where many of Kenya’s running champions come from. A graduate of the London School of Economics, Navalayo has worked in different places around the world, including the US, UK, Ethiopia, Tanzania and Kenya. She is trained as both an accountant and a lawyer, which explains why she is so interested in risk management, results-based management and writing.Weldon is a social-change campaigner who has worked on a range of early stage social change startups. He built the student and international member programs at The ONE Campaign and most recently led Change.org's growth in Europe as the regional Managing Director. An avid runner and running shoe obsessive, his half marathon PB is 1:37:39.We met in Nairobi in early 2015 and immediately clicked. After a couple of conversations we decided to found Enda because we believe Kenya can, and should, benefit more from it’s well earned running reputation, and because we believe it will be good for runners everywhere to have a stronger connection to the culture and traditions of Kenyan running. Social ImpactWe are a social enterprise with a mission of increasing the amount Kenya benefits from its well earned reputation in running greatness. We’re working with social impact consultants, Global & Smart, to ensure that we’re building a company that has creating social value at it’s core right from the start.1. Creating Jobs This is pretty straight forward. Kenya is a young country with a median age of 18 years. Frustratingly, youth unemployment in Kenya is 17%. Development experts and the Kenyan government agree that creating good jobs in sectors like manufacturing is one of the most important priorities for the country.The challenge is that it is almost always cheaper and easier to produce goods in Southeast Asia. We plan on overcoming this obstacle by creating a brand that leverages the value of being made in Kenya, as well as taking advantage of preferential of tariff rates for importing footwear and apparel to the US under the African Growth and Opportunity Act. The result will be bringing some quality jobs to Kenya.2. Supporting Local CommunitiesMany Kenyans lack access to basic sanitation, clean water, adequate health care, and quality education. Thankfully many clever and courageous people are working to address these challenges. From experience, we know how hard it is for them to fund their activities. We want to make sure we’re making our contribution too, so here’s how we’re going to do this:
We’ll set aside a portion of our profits into a pool (of money, not for swimming!)
column2: Working with experts, we’ll identify a handful of most effective projects that could use some extra support every 6 months

column1: Anyone who buys a pair of Enda shoes and registers their purchase will get one vote to help us determine which projects will receive money from the pool
Through this, we will link Enda runners across the globe to local communities in Kenya, and vice versa, and encourage empathy, creativity and innovation.

3. Changing The Way the World Sees KenyaKenya is already famous for the world’s best runners, stunning wildlife, fantastic beaches, and where President Obama’s father came from (never mind the rest of our species some 60,000 years ago). We want to make it famous for great products too.Most people couldn’t tell you exactly where their shoes are made. We want Enda runners to be able to take pride in knowing their running kit comes from Kenya, and that Kenyan products are of the highest quality. Share Enda On Social MediaThink we're amazing? Well then, don't keep it to yourself! Follow us on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram and share us with your family and friends!!!Risks and challengesWe don’t think we’re the first people to think up the idea of making running shoes in Kenya. Certainly the idea has dawned on others, but they haven’t done it because it’s a downright difficult thing to do. Here are the top challenges we foresee, though knowing they might come up, we’re already working hard to mitigate their potential impact.Import and Export Challenges - there are an increasing number of companies bringing materials into Kenya and exporting finished goods. The more companies do it, the smoother the process becomes. Still, the port at Mombasa is known to be challenging and slowdowns can occur. We’ll work with the best handling agents to mitigate this risk and hopefully be able to assemble and ship our shoes on schedule.Shipping and Delivery - There may be other fees, forms or legalities we are unaware of that could block shipments of the shoes or cause them to be delayed or returned. While we're not experts on tax and other fees applicable to every country, we will do our best to ensure that your order arrives on time.Consistency and Quality Control - when we start putting together a large volume of shoes for the first time, we’ll have to work hard to ensure they are consistently of the highest quality. We’re factoring this into our costs, and anticipate that there will be some shoes early on that won’t be up to our standards so we'll have some shoes we can’t ship.Achieving Social Good Goals - all of our social good goals depend on us becoming a sustainable and scalable business. This Indiegogo campaign will get things rolling, but we’ll only really start creating jobs and revenue to Kenya if the attention and funds from the campaign get us to the point where we’re producing and selling a steady stream of shoes. So we’re already diving into a marketing plan for online sales, and will start selling to stores for the Spring 2017 season.Sizing - we’ve worked hard to ensure our shoes run true to size. However, there’s always a chance that slight variations in foot shape mean that an Enda runner finds they need a slightly different size from their other running shoes. We’ll be using a distribution service to ensure returns are handled smoothly and efficiently.Production Speed - making prototypes and a full production run are two totally different things, and there are likely unforeseen pitfalls we aren’t seeing yet. We don’t want to over-promise on this first production run, so we’ve added in extra padding on our production timelines. If we have any doubt that we’ll be able to hit delivery timelines we’ll be open and forthcoming so you know when to expect the shoes.",14.0,0,"1 Campaign

Important! If you want more sets - at Indiegogo you can buy more than one perk!

Since the beginning of this campaign lot of you speak out the wish to get these keycaps with the classic „C 64 Breadbin“ - layout. Instead of the cost saving „top down“ - layout from the later C64 like the C64G.

We didn’t offer this from the beginning, because this means a lot of extra costs and working hours. Thereby a higher goal to reach, maybe than a little bit to much... nobody knows.

But now we are save, so we can make you the following offer: If the campaign reaches 30.000,- Euro we are able to offer the classic „C64 Breadbin“- layout for the keycaps as an extra option to choose. As a free upgrade (2nd bonus stage) for all orders placed during this Indiegogo campaign. As a small thank you to all people who believed in this project.

But please notice – producing this keycaps requires a greater effort than originally planned. So if you choose the „C64 Breadbin“- layout option for one or more sets the shipment of your whole order will have a delay of four to six weeks. 

This extra option will cause no delay to the shipment of orders which only contains the first offered „top down“- layout.


The unique opportunity to order brand new, 100% factory-made in Austria keycaps for the Commodore C64 in a variety of colours. Keycaps fit virtually all C64 versions (except the C64SX), but also most VC20 / C16 and some Commodore CBM!

Hi, my name is Michael and I have been a big Commodore fan since I had my first VC 20. For over 25 years I’ve been collecting everything by this company, totalling over 1,000 pieces: typewriters, desktop calculators, hand-held calculators and of course computers – I own almost every device Commodore ever produced, from the PET 2001 to the A4000T.

So I was very excited when I heard of a campaign to finance new housings in a variety of colours. And what do new coloured housings need just as much as old ones? That’s right! New keycaps, without yellowing, available in a variety of colours. So the stunning look of a new housing won’t be ruined by ugly, old keys.

Unfortunately although injection moulded parts aren’t difficult to produce, the moulds and tools are extremely expensive. The injection mould for the Commodore C64 keys including planning and manufacturing would far exceed 40,000.- Dollars. Normally unaffordable since there is far too little demand, but now...
Now there is a unique opportunity for all true C64 fans from around the world by two coinciding situations:

1. Thanks to a wonderful “lucky sod” from Dallas, new housings will be released in a variety of colours. Lots of people bought them, maybe including you. I am absolutely convinced that many buyers will also want new, beautiful and matching keycaps, so currently there is a higher demand than ever before and probably ever will be.

2. Through my job as a machine retailer for metal and plastic processing I meet a lot of people who deal with tool and mould making and even injection moulding. More specifically, we sell machines to these companies. So I would have the opportunity to have the right injection mould designed and manufactured far below the typical costs – and along with it, keycaps for our precious Commodore 64!
Once the campaign is completed and we have reached the goal, we commission a new injection mould for the keycaps and start the production right away!
The keycaps will fit all common C64 versions such as:
Please check if your computer is compatible before buying. Simply remove a keycap and compare it with our picture.

Of course the keycaps will be produced in ALL classic colours to match the units in the list above. But also in some new colours. At the moment we are planning to produce the caps in following (classic &
We will add more colours in the next few weeks.
The translucent / frosted (like the 90ies iMacs G3) upgrade perk is available from now! The colours are White (Snow), Black, Blue and Red.
The keys will be shipped in complete sets with all keycaps including function keys in the colour you ordered - e. g. Black.

If you want a combination like light blue keycaps with blue function keys you have to order an additional 4-piece set of blue functions keys. There is no other way because we can only use one colour per production run.
Please note – some spacebars and “Shift Lock” keys may need an additional base. You must keep those parts from the old keyboard!

The keycaps will be produced by mid August and will be shipped shortly thereafter. Packing and shipping worldwide (except the North and South Pole) is 10.- Euro. No matter where to and how many sets you order, you only pay 10.- Euro one-time fee! Please don’t forget to add this amount to your support!

This is not the motto of our campaign, since we don’t see a high risk. Building injection moulds and producing injection moulded parts is not rocket science. It is beeing done hundreds of million times a day!

column5: >Production, distribution and shipping are also normal day-to-day business. For the past 10 years our company has supported and supplied thousands of customers worldwide, so distribution and shipping logistics are not a big challenge for us. We have years of experience in this field.

column1: The keycaps are injection moulded in industrial production
column2: the extremely high costs of the tool are also “to blame” for the finance amount of this campaign.

column1: The shape of the keycaps will be as close to the classic concave shape as possible, each keyboard row will have its own shape with the correct angles and axes. Differences compared to the original keyboard will be minimal, if any. Under no circumstances will we produce the flat keyboard the C64X had.
What material will the keycaps be made from and will this material yellow?

The keycaps are made from PC + ASA granulate. This very high quality plastic granulate is used in many fields, ranging from the medical field or the aircraft industry, all the way to the automotive industry. This granulate contains no additives so it is certain to prevent discolouration or yellowing.

The keys are imprinted with the pad printing process, just as virtually all keyboards currently being manufactured. It provides a crisp and clear print image which stays clean for years, even with daily use.

Just as Commodore (z. B. C64G) at the time, we decided on complete printing from the top for financial reasons, the layout corresponds with the US International layout. Unfortunately, at this volume, printing the classic symbols on the front is unaffordable.
How can I choose the keytop colour?

Once the campaign has successfully ended, we will send you a link to our processing system shortly before production starts. Here you can then choose colours, order additional features, change the delivery address, or pay the shipping charges (if you forgot).
Yes, we offer translucent (like the 90ies iMac G3) keycaps in Snow, Blue and Red.

The name “Commodore” and the logo are still registered and using them without the trademark owner’s permission is prohibited. We’ve tried to contact the trademark owner several times, but to no avail. We plan (as shown in the pictures) to simply imprint the respective key with “C” or “C=”.
Will you also have other keyboard layouts?
Different layouts require different print templates. These add significant costs, and considering the volume it’s unfortunately not feasible.
Why aren’t there more colours to choose from at the moment?
Switching colours in production also involves costs. Costs for stopping production, cleaning the machine, and the production waste. We purposely did not include these added costs in the price
column2: we were more focused on an inexpensive product than thousands of colours.

column1: Why is shipping 10.- Euro more, not free of charge?

Because there is no such thing as free shipping. With free shipping, sellers simply “hide” the shipping costs in the retail price. We could have done the same, free shipping – but then every set would have been 29.- Euro. But this would have been unfair to those buying several sets or perks, since they would have paid multiple shipping charges. That’s why we offer the “Shipping” perk, which you only need to apply once. No matter how many sets you’re buying – saving you cash!

Thanks alot for your time and support!

Hello, I’m Karolina, the person behind the 'Karolina Laskowska' lingerie brand! I'm a total lingerie addict (with my own excessive collection) and it was this love of lingerie that led me to designing it myself.

I’ve been making lingerie for a few years now – it originally started off as sewing one-off pieces for myself and for photoshoots, well before I even had any technical lingerie knowledge.  It was in the Summer of last year that I launched my brand, opening an online shop and getting my first wholesale stockist.  I’ve had more success and support than I could have imagined.  I sew everything myself, making the lingerie to order.  As proud as I am of what I’ve achieved in this short period of time, I want to move the brand forward
column2: I feel that I’ve moved on, both in terms of my technical knowledge and design wise, and I want my brand to reflect that.  The new collection that I’ve been designing showcases my love of couture-quality lace and luxurious silks, without compromising on my signature design aesthetic.

column1: 'Luiza': one of the designs from the new collection, featuring couture beaded and embroidered chantilly lace.

However, this new collection doesn’t come without its problems-  it’s more complex and takes significantly longer to sew. I’m still studying at university and this Autumn will be beginning my final year - I know now that I simply won’t have the time to sew orders myself anymore, considering how heavy the workload will be.  In the past year there were periods where I was forced to close my online shop because I simply couldn’t cope with the volume of orders.

It was never my intention to properly start a brand whilst I was still studying but it seemed to evolve into that – and now that it’s happened, it’s not something I just want to give up and put totally on hiatus for a year until I finish my degree.   I’d feel like I was totally abandoning and letting down all of the people who’ve been following and supporting me in this time!
Details of kimono silk knickers and matching nipple pasties

I do have a solution to this problem though – I want this new collection to be manufactured for me. By having the lingerie manufactured for me instead of sewing it all myself there’s plenty of benefits – there’ll no longer be a month’s waiting time for orders, it won’t cost as much as when garments are made individually, and the machinists will have a wealth of sewing experience well beyond anything I have. If I have the lingerie manufactured for me, I’ll be able to keep the brand running next year and I’ll be able to fulfil more wholesale orders – giving you far better opportunities to actually buy my designs.
'Ela': another set from the new collection - a revamp of an older one-off design with improved fit.

I started this brand with no real funding and I continue to do so. Unlike so many other lingerie brands that you may be familiar with, I have absolutely no investors or savings to start with. I am still a student, and live on a student budget – everything I’ve done so far has been done out of what little money I could spare. Materials have been bought in small quantities and I’d make garments one by one in what spare time I could find.  This new collection is the result of over a year’s worth of saving and buying materials bit by bit. Whilst I’ve managed to acquire the majority of fabrics and components for the new collection (the stunning leavers laces and kimono fabrics that the whole aesthetic is based upon), there are still elements that I’m struggling to afford – things you may not even consider, such as lining fabrics, elastic trims, tags and labels.   Realistically, my funding goal isn’t enough to fund a lingerie collection but I’m determined to make it work no matter how much is raised.  I’m visiting the factory I intend to use in Poland at the end of June regardless of how this campaign goes!

The new collection will consist of three brand new lingerie sets and a mini collection of knickers. The 'Luiza' set uses embroidered and beaded black chantilly lace in an open cup wired bra and matching hip-fin short. 'Ela' is a revamp of an older one-off design and uses metallic gold and rose leavers lace in a signature strappy soft cup bra and high waisted brief. 'Monika' is a champagne chantilly lace set with a brief and soft bra.  The knicker collection will be based around my collection of vintage kimono fabrics, with high-waisted briefs and matching pasties. Each design will be one-of-a-kind due to the finite nature of the fabrics!

If I raise enough money I will also have some of my last collection's 'strappy' designs put into production and make them permanently available. I haven't decided which of these they will be though so I will be running a poll through social media soon to help decide which to keep and which to say goodbye to!
'Monika' - Couture chantilly lace soft bra and brief set from the new collection

So, what will you get in return for contributing to this campaign?  I do of course, have some incredibly awesome and exciting rewards!  They range from just £1 to a rather substantial £750 and include everything from signed illustration prints, mystery accessories and knickers, exclusively designed lingerie and harnesses (literally ONLY available through this campaign!) and even totally bespoke lingerie. I hope there’s something to tickle everyone’s fancy!  Throughout this project I’ll be keeping a special blog documenting the progress and behind the scenes that every contributor above the £5 mark will be able to access.
Mystery knickers - you could be the owner of a similar pair!

I’ll also be running other fundraising activities outside this crowdfunder through my website and my other social media and would hugely appreciate all the help I can get.  Even if you can’t contribute money then it would be amazing if you could share this with your friends and family and on social media.

I am of course happy to answer any questions you might have about the project and campaign so feel free to tweet, email or leave comments and I’ll make sure that I get back to you.  I hope you’re as excited about this project as I am – fingers crossed we can make it happen!

column2:
bruises (Plurabelle) / CC BY-NC-SA 3.0

","Hello, I’m Karolina, the person behind the 'Karolina Laskowska' lingerie brand! I'm a total lingerie addict (with my own excessive collection) and it was this love of lingerie that led me to designing it myself.

column1: I’ve been making lingerie for a few years now – it originally started off as sewing one-off pieces for myself and for photoshoots, well before I even had any technical lingerie knowledge.  It was in the Summer of last year that I launched my brand, opening an online shop and getting my first wholesale stockist.  I’ve had more success and support than I could have imagined.  I sew everything myself, making the lingerie to order.  As proud as I am of what I’ve achieved in this short period of time, I want to move the brand forward
column2: I feel that I’ve moved on, both in terms of my technical knowledge and design wise, and I want my brand to reflect that.  The new collection that I’ve been designing showcases my love of couture-quality lace and luxurious silks, without compromising on my signature design aesthetic.

column1: 'Luiza': one of the designs from the new collection, featuring couture beaded and embroidered chantilly lace.

However, this new collection doesn’t come without its problems-  it’s more complex and takes significantly longer to sew. I’m still studying at university and this Autumn will be beginning my final year - I know now that I simply won’t have the time to sew orders myself anymore, considering how heavy the workload will be.  In the past year there were periods where I was forced to close my online shop because I simply couldn’t cope with the volume of orders.

It was never my intention to properly start a brand whilst I was still studying but it seemed to evolve into that – and now that it’s happened, it’s not something I just want to give up and put totally on hiatus for a year until I finish my degree.   I’d feel like I was totally abandoning and letting down all of the people who’ve been following and supporting me in this time!
Details of kimono silk knickers and matching nipple pasties

I do have a solution to this problem though – I want this new collection to be manufactured for me. By having the lingerie manufactured for me instead of sewing it all myself there’s plenty of benefits – there’ll no longer be a month’s waiting time for orders, it won’t cost as much as when garments are made individually, and the machinists will have a wealth of sewing experience well beyond anything I have. If I have the lingerie manufactured for me, I’ll be able to keep the brand running next year and I’ll be able to fulfil more wholesale orders – giving you far better opportunities to actually buy my designs.
'Ela': another set from the new collection - a revamp of an older one-off design with improved fit.

I started this brand with no real funding and I continue to do so. Unlike so many other lingerie brands that you may be familiar with, I have absolutely no investors or savings to start with. I am still a student, and live on a student budget – everything I’ve done so far has been done out of what little money I could spare. Materials have been bought in small quantities and I’d make garments one by one in what spare time I could find.  This new collection is the result of over a year’s worth of saving and buying materials bit by bit. Whilst I’ve managed to acquire the majority of fabrics and components for the new collection (the stunning leavers laces and kimono fabrics that the whole aesthetic is based upon), there are still elements that I’m struggling to afford – things you may not even consider, such as lining fabrics, elastic trims, tags and labels.   Realistically, my funding goal isn’t enough to fund a lingerie collection but I’m determined to make it work no matter how much is raised.  I’m visiting the factory I intend to use in Poland at the end of June regardless of how this campaign goes!

The new collection will consist of three brand new lingerie sets and a mini collection of knickers. The 'Luiza' set uses embroidered and beaded black chantilly lace in an open cup wired bra and matching hip-fin short. 'Ela' is a revamp of an older one-off design and uses metallic gold and rose leavers lace in a signature strappy soft cup bra and high waisted brief. 'Monika' is a champagne chantilly lace set with a brief and soft bra.  The knicker collection will be based around my collection of vintage kimono fabrics, with high-waisted briefs and matching pasties. Each design will be one-of-a-kind due to the finite nature of the fabrics!

If I raise enough money I will also have some of my last collection's 'strappy' designs put into production and make them permanently available. I haven't decided which of these they will be though so I will be running a poll through social media soon to help decide which to keep and which to say goodbye to!
'Monika' - Couture chantilly lace soft bra and brief set from the new collection

So, what will you get in return for contributing to this campaign?  I do of course, have some incredibly awesome and exciting rewards!  They range from just £1 to a rather substantial £750 and include everything from signed illustration prints, mystery accessories and knickers, exclusively designed lingerie and harnesses (literally ONLY available through this campaign!) and even totally bespoke lingerie. I hope there’s something to tickle everyone’s fancy!  Throughout this project I’ll be keeping a special blog documenting the progress and behind the scenes that every contributor above the £5 mark will be able to access.
Mystery knickers - you could be the owner of a similar pair!

I’ll also be running other fundraising activities outside this crowdfunder through my website and my other social media and would hugely appreciate all the help I can get.  Even if you can’t contribute money then it would be amazing if you could share this with your friends and family and on social media.

I am of course happy to answer any questions you might have about the project and campaign so feel free to tweet, email or leave comments and I’ll make sure that I get back to you.  I hope you’re as excited about this project as I am – fingers crossed we can make it happen!
Video music: cuts&bruises (Plurabelle) / CC BY-NC-SA 3.0",5.0,0,"2 Campaigns

The Day it Happened:
As my wife and I drove to a family gathering, We were talking about church that morning that I had attended. The discussion was
column2: doing for others. It got both of us to thinking, what can we do right now to help others that we ourselves take for granted and at that moment it happened. A gentleman was standing on the corner of our intersection not asking for money but food… Anything if possible, now normally I DO NOT ever give money to the homeless but food, that is a different story. We were in route to a family dinner and had 4 loafs of artisan bread with us, without even discussing it both my wife and I reached to grab one to give to him and we kind of laughed at first that we had the same idea at the same time. We gave the man the food and he called over 2 other family members waiting in a car nearby and split it between them 2 very small kids and his wife and yes it does seem they were living out of the car. We didn’t stop for long as we were already late but , the whole rest of the trip we started thinking how can you make a balanced meal and spend the least amount of money, to maximize the amount of people you can affect….

column1: • We are looking to raise at the very least $200, with that much money we can feed 220 people.
• We found a way to make a sack lunch with a Ham and cheese sandwich, bag of veggie sticks\chips and a bottle of water for only .97 cents each, shopping off name brands and in bulk.
• The funds will go directly to create as many of these brown bags as we can to get to the homeless and less fortunate

With a simple $4.00 donation you can feed a family of 4 people that might not otherwise have a meal that day… This is going to directly affect hungry persons here in your back yard. We are hoping that this will catch on and people can start a Brown Bag Project in their own hometowns, so that America’s hungry are no more. We are not giving these things out at a church or community center we are going to find these persons on our own, face to face in our community.

More Fab You!

where fabulous fashion and fabulous causes coincide 

The founder...Meet Liz

A long-time dream to start a business that will market independent fashion in support of social causes is finally taking shape. More Fab You was born out of my love for fashion and style and my innate drive to ensure that every day I'm doing something to enhance another life. I believe that by wearing fashion that embodies a cause people will inevitably feel more fabulous about themselves and others, hence a More Fab You, a More Fab Us, a More Fab World.


The company
column2: >More Fab You is a lifestyle fashion brand where fashion and fabulous causes coincide. Our mission is to continually market independent design while supporting relevant causes and organizations who truly need us.
column4: >Each MFY apparel piece is designed with love and uniqueness. Our hope is that through the creation and distribution of MFY designs and other cause-oriented fashion group apparel we can together enhance our world in a variety
column7:
>We believe doing fabulous things will allow us all to feel more fabulous!

What's the first MFY Fashion Mission?

With your help, the first fashion mission is to execute the production and sales of our MFY legging line for our Leggings for Trunks campaign.  We adore elephants (all animals in fact) and we'd like to utilize a portion of our legging sales to support wildlife organizations in support of elephants and other wildlife preservation efforts.

This is just the first of many fabulous MFY Fashion missions to come...we're relying on you all to continue telling us about causes you feel most passionate about so we can support as many awesome things in this world as possible. All through fabulous fashion and design!

Please join us on the MFY journey and thank you so much for helping us realize our vision. A more fab you means a more fab us and most importantly a more fab world. 

With huge love and gratitude,

MFY :)
